unnormalised: Okay, here's a Quora post, written in a narrative style, about Indian Railways, incorporating Indian English and unnormalized data, targeting a length of 7+ paragraphs.
normalised: I've traveled extensively across India, and I can safely say that nothing quite compares to the experience of traveling by Indian Railways. It's not just a mode of transport; it's a microcosm of India itself. The sheer variety of people you meet, the sounds, the smells – it's an assault on the senses in the best possible way.

unnormalised: I've traveled extensively across India, and I can safely say that nothing quite compares to the experience of traveling by Indian Railways. It's not just a mode of transport; it's a microcosm of India itself. The sheer variety of people you meet, the sounds, the smells – it's an assault on the senses in the best possible way.
normalised: My most memorable train journey was from Delhi to Guwahati on the Rajdhani Express. I booked a three A C ticket well in advance. It was during Durga Puja, and the train was packed! I arrived at New Delhi Railway Station at six P M, a bit early to find my berth. The platform was already teeming with people, chai wallahs yelling, and the general chaos that you expect at any major Indian railway station. I managed to find my compartment, and surprisingly, it wasn't too difficult to stow my luggage.

unnormalised: My most memorable train journey was from Delhi to Guwahati on the Rajdhani Express. I booked a 3AC ticket well in advance. It was during Durga Puja, and the train was packed! I arrived at New Delhi Railway Station at 06:00 PM, a bit early to find my berth. The platform was already teeming with people, chai wallahs yelling, and the general chaos that you expect at any major Indian railway station. I managed to find my compartment, and surprisingly, it wasn't too difficult to stow my luggage.
normalised: The train left on time, exactly at seven P M, and soon we were speeding through the night. I was sharing my compartment with a family of four from Kolkata, going back home for the puja holidays. They were incredibly friendly and offered me homemade snacks – singara and rosogolla. We chatted for hours about everything from Bollywood movies to the rising prices of dal.

unnormalised: The train left on time, exactly at 07:00 PM, and soon we were speeding through the night. I was sharing my compartment with a family of four from Kolkata, going back home for the puja holidays. They were incredibly friendly and offered me homemade snacks – singara and rosogolla. We chatted for hours about everything from Bollywood movies to the rising prices of dal.
normalised: Around eight thirty P M, dinner was served – the standard railway fare of roti, dal, sabzi, and rice. Not exactly gourmet cuisine, but filling and satisfying. After dinner, I tried to get some sleep, but the constant rattling of the train and the snoring of my fellow passengers made it a bit challenging. I did manage to doze off for a few hours.

unnormalised: Around 08:30 PM, dinner was served – the standard railway fare of roti, dal, sabzi, and rice. Not exactly gourmet cuisine, but filling and satisfying. After dinner, I tried to get some sleep, but the constant rattling of the train and the snoring of my fellow passengers made it a bit challenging. I did manage to doze off for a few hours.
normalised: The next morning, I woke up to the stunning views of the Bengal countryside. Lush green fields, small villages, and the occasional glimpse of the Brahmaputra river. We reached Guwahati at four P M, about thirty minutes late, but I didn't mind. The journey itself was the destination. I will need to take a cab, costing around rupees five hundred, to get to my final location.

unnormalised: The next morning, I woke up to the stunning views of the Bengal countryside. Lush green fields, small villages, and the occasional glimpse of the Brahmaputra river. We reached Guwahati at 04:00 PM, about 30 minutes late, but I didn't mind. The journey itself was the destination. I will need to take a cab, costing around Rs. 500, to get to my final location.
normalised: Indian Railways isn't just about getting from point A to point B. It's about the experiences you have along the way. It's about the chai you share with strangers, the stories you hear, and the memories you make. Sure, there are delays, the toilets might not always be spotless, and the food can be hit or miss, but that's all part of the charm. I highly recommend everyone to try it at least once. Even the unreserved sitting is amazing.

unnormalised: Indian Railways isn't just about getting from point A to point B. It's about the experiences you have along the way. It's about the chai you share with strangers, the stories you hear, and the memories you make. Sure, there are delays, the toilets might not always be spotless, and the food can be hit or miss, but that's all part of the charm. I highly recommend everyone to try it at least once. Even the unreserved sitting is amazing.
normalised: I know people complain, but for me, it's the best way to see India. Next time I’m traveling, I am taking the train, even if it takes twenty four plus hours to reach my destination.

unnormalised: I know people complain, but for me, it's the best way to see India. Next time I’m traveling, I am taking the train, even if it takes 24+ hrs to reach my destination.
